Title: Cache invalidation isn't a hard problem
Description: Cache invalidation is often said to be a hard problem to solve. I don't think this is true in the context of software systems.

Title: Procrastination by Reading
Description: Reading all these books doesn't mean you will be successful unless you execute on your learnings. Reading and executing should run in parallel.

Title: Settings are not a design failure
Description: The systematic thinking in our industry is that settings are the result of design failure. As designers, our goal is to create product experiences that don’t require any adjustment by the user. So offering customization options is often seen as a failure to make firm product decisions. I think there is a misunderstanding about what settings really are.

Title: Don’t Add Salt to Baby Food: The Surprisingly Weak Evidence for Infant Sodium Requirements - Lily Nichols RDN

weeks because I’ve been busy working on this:

Title: Finding unknown sensors with I²C probing
Description: The Mainline4Lumia project aims to bring mainline Linux to the Nokia/Microsoft Lumia phone series, which run a version of Windows Phone. We were making progress quickly, enabling I²C components such as the touchscreen and proximity/light sensor with information found in the stock UEFI tables. However, we couldn’t find any information regarding other sensors (accelerometer, gyroscope, magnetometer in the files; not even any GPIO references or I²C bus addresses. Unlike Android devices, which run a fork of the Linux kernel, we can’t go and look at the downstream kernel source - so I delved into the schematics to find out.

Title: Caching Header Best Practices
Description: Caching headers are surprisingly complex and often misconfigured. Here we look at some key cache scenarios and recommend the ideal headers to set.

Title: Hacks for engineering estimates - shubhro.com
Description: Engineers often have to ask each other for “estimates”– rough projections for how long projects will take. While some teams do rigorous estimation rituals to varying degrees of success, many situations simply require answering based on gut feel.

Title: Who keeps an eye on clipboard access? – Gonçalo Valério
Description: If there is any feature that “universally” describes the usage of computers, it is the copy/paste pattern. We are used to it, practically all the common graphical user interfaces have support for it, and it magically works.
